item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“adamp40, post:22, topic:255062”]I still dont understand why my 3Ghz (which isnt bad) Pentinum 4 gets hot even when streaming HD video!

The fan makes such a loud noise!

Is this to do with my lack of RAM (512mb) :([/quote]

No, CPU temperatures would have nothing to do with the amount of RAM you have, however it could be because your fan is bad (especially if it is making a loud noise.

Read full topic
item.source: Going to Order, what do you think?

item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“adamp40, post:22, topic:255062”]I still dont understand why my 3Ghz (which isnt bad) Pentinum 4 gets hot even when streaming HD video!

The fan makes such a loud noise!

Is this to do with my lack of RAM (512mb) :([/quote]GHZ is not everything, a 4ghz pentium 4 has the equivalent speed of a 2ghz core 2 duo.

Friend and I both have 3.0ghz, we ran a test using SuperPI a cpu speed test. My cpu being Core 2 duo E6850, his AMD Athlon 6000+, both 2 cores, he finished the test at 30 seconds whilst mine did 14. (lower the better)

Read full topic

item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I’m just gonna go totally against the grain and say if you’re happy with what you got, get the OEM CPU and the aftermarket cooler. That’s what I do, I prefer aftermarket coolers anyway (perhaps a habit from years gone by, but fuck it it make sme feel better about it :P).

Read full topic

@FastBallz wrote:

[quote=“adamp40, post:5, topic:255062”]Not really… I think a decent CPU cooler is essential to a PC. I get really pissed off when my PC’s Fan starts making the loudest sound known to man! I would rather the thing overheat then make such a loud noise.

If you want to overclock a PC, Dry Ice is the best way to cool- Some guy overclcked a 3GHz single core to 8GHz :)[/quote]

item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

OEM everything else is alright, just don’t get an OEM CPU. The reason for this is one that they don’t come with coolers, and two that instead of a 3 year warranty, they have a 30 day warranty usually. Plus a regular one is usually only slightly more than an OEM version anyhow.

Read full topic

item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Basically same rig I used to have. Right now my current one is a little better (CPU&GPU, everything else is equal).

I like it. Whatever you do just install a 64bit OS on it.

My 64 runs SO much better than my old 32.

they come in crappy packaging that doesn’t seem to protect the parts as much. I bought a samsung HDD oem that came in a flimsy plastic sleeve and it failed right after I installed windows.

item.source: Going to Order, what do you think?

item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“adamp40, post:5, topic:255062”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=337031.msg2617980#msg2617980 date=1231176221]
save your money on that CPU cooler
[/quote]

Not really… I think a decent CPU cooler is essential to a PC. I get really pissed off when my PC’s Fan starts making the loudest sound known to man! I would rather the thing overheat then make such a loud noise.

If you want to overclock a PC, Dry Ice is the best way to cool- Some guy overclcked a 3GHz single core to 8GHz :)[/quote]tell me someone who uses dry ice/liquid nitrogen to play thier computers normally. I’m sure the threadstarter isnt trying to break any records or brag about benchmarks. With the intel CPU’s these days like mitb said they are fine. Definitely no need for an aftermarket one unless you plan on overclocking (even the ones that come with the CPU you can squeeze a few hundred mhz out of)

Read full topic
item.source: Going to Order, what do you think?

item.title: Going to Order, what do you think?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Really though, you don’t need that extra CPU cooler. Back in the day when I started building computers and the best CPU you could buy was an AMD Athlon XP we used to buy aftermarket CPU coolers because the stock ones that AMD provided were super-loud and ran very hot. Now the coolers that come with the latest intel chips have copper cores, are quiet, and are just about the best coolers that you can get. My computer runs between 30 and 35 degrees with the stock cooler, and I have an older, hotter running c2d.

Read full topic
